title: How are the first few lines of the Akkadian Epic of Atrahasis written in cuneiform? - Quora

response.answer_text: i-nu-ma i-lu a-wi-lum (when the gods, manlike...) ub-lu du-ul-la iz-bi-lu shu-up-shi-ik-ka (bore the toil, carried the load)  Transliteration and translation from THE ATRAHASIS EPIC and Its Place in Babylonian Literature. Thesis submitted for the Degree of Master of Philosophy by Alan Ralph MILLARD University of London May,1966 https://eprints.soas.ac.uk/29625/1/10752597.pdf Image of tablet 1 from CUNEIFORM TEXTS FROM BABYLONIAN TABLETS IN THE BRITISH MUSEUM PART XLVI BABYLONIAN LITERARY TEXTS BY W.G. LAMBERT & A.R. MILLARD PUBLISHED BY THE TRUSTEES OF THE BRITISH MUSEUM, LONDON 1965 http://www.etana.org/sites/default/files/coretexts/20449.pdf

Adding to David Lipovitch’s answer (and from the same source)…  The top line is the Old Babylonian orthography, and the second line is the Neo-Assyrian orthography. Sorry the image is small, but hopefully that gets you in the right direction. From The Babylonian Story of the Flood by Lambert and Millard, 1969. Sign list is from Borger’s Mesopotamisches Zeichenlexikon, 2004.
